questions.q: Which structural feature best distinguishes a muscular artery from an elastic artery in histologic sections?
options: Presence of multiple elastic lamellae in the tunica media
Relatively thick tunica media rich in smooth muscle cells
questions.answer: Relatively thick tunica media rich in smooth muscle cells
questions.topic: Cardiovascular System: Blood Vessels and Heart

questions.q: In a medium-sized vein, which layer is typically the thickest and most prominent?
questions.topic: Cardiovascular System: Blood Vessels and Heart

questions.q: Which chamber of the heart contains prominent trabeculae carneae and papillary muscles anchored to chordae tendineae?
questions.topic: Cardiovascular System: Blood Vessels and Heart

questions.q: Which specialized cardiac junction ensures rapid electrical coupling between adjacent cardiomyocytes?
questions.topic: Cardiovascular System: Blood Vessels and Heart

questions.q: What is the main functional role of elastic arteries such as the aorta in the circulation?
options: Act as primary resistance vessels to control blood pressure
Serve as exchange vessels for gases and nutrients
Dampen pulsatile output of the heart to maintain continuous blood flow
Provide a major site for leukocyte diapedesis
questions.answer: Dampen pulsatile output of the heart to maintain continuous blood flow
questions.topic: Cardiovascular System: Blood Vessels and Heart

questions.q: Which cell type is the immediate precursor of erythrocytes in the bone marrow?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System I: Blood and Bone Marrow

questions.q: Which leukocyte is characterized by a bilobed nucleus and large eosinophilic specific granules in the cytoplasm?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System I: Blood and Bone Marrow

questions.q: Which statement best describes the function of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow?
options: They give rise to platelets by cytoplasmic fragmentation
They secrete antibodies in response to antigens
questions.answer: They give rise to platelets by cytoplasmic fragmentation
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System I: Blood and Bone Marrow

questions.q: Which component of circulating blood is anucleate and essential for primary hemostasis?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System I: Blood and Bone Marrow

questions.q: Which feature best describes a mature erythrocyte under light microscopy?
options: Large cell with central nucleus and basophilic cytoplasm
Biconcave disc without nucleus and with eosinophilic cytoplasm
Small cell with large nucleus and scant cytoplasm
Cell with azurophilic granules and kidney-shaped nucleus
questions.answer: Biconcave disc without nucleus and with eosinophilic cytoplasm
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System I: Blood and Bone Marrow

questions.q: Which lymphoid organ is characterized by a cortex with lymphoid follicles and a medulla with medullary cords and sinuses?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System II: Lymphoid Organs

questions.q: The periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS) is a characteristic feature of which organ?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System II: Lymphoid Organs

questions.q: Which region of a lymph node is primarily populated by T lymphocytes?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System II: Lymphoid Organs

questions.q: Which statement best describes the thymus in an adult?
options: It lacks a cortex and medulla
It continues active lymphopoiesis throughout life without involution
It shows age-related fatty replacement with residual lymphoid tissue
It contains Hassall corpuscles only in the cortex
questions.answer: It shows age-related fatty replacement with residual lymphoid tissue
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System II: Lymphoid Organs

questions.q: Hassall corpuscles are concentrically arranged epithelial reticular cells found in which part of the thymus?
questions.topic: Hematopoietic and Lymphoid System II: Lymphoid Organs

questions.q: Which papillae of the tongue contain taste buds and are arranged in a V-shaped row anterior to the sulcus terminalis?
questions.topic: Digestive System I: Oral Cavity, Esophagus, and Stomach

questions.q: The esophagus is lined by which type of epithelium?
options: Simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells
questions.topic: Digestive System I: Oral Cavity, Esophagus, and Stomach

questions.q: Which cell type in the gastric glands secretes hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor?
questions.topic: Digestive System I: Oral Cavity, Esophagus, and Stomach

questions.q: Which region of the stomach contains prominent mucous secreting glands in the lamina propria that protect the esophageal mucosa from gastric acid?
questions.topic: Digestive System I: Oral Cavity, Esophagus, and Stomach

questions.q: Which structure is responsible for increasing surface area in the stomach but disappears when the organ is distended?
questions.topic: Digestive System I: Oral Cavity, Esophagus, and Stomach

questions.q: Which feature best distinguishes the jejunum from the ileum histologically?
options: Presence of Brunner glands in the submucosa
Numerous long villi and prominent plicae circulares
Abundant Peyer patches in the lamina propria and submucosa
Absence of goblet cells in the epithelium
questions.answer: Numerous long villi and prominent plicae circulares
questions.topic: Digestive System II: Small and Large Intestine

questions.q: Which specialized glands in the duodenum secrete alkaline mucus to neutralize gastric acid?
questions.topic: Digestive System II: Small and Large Intestine

questions.q: Which structure is present in the large intestine but absent in the small intestine?
questions.topic: Digestive System II: Small and Large Intestine

questions.q: Which cell type in the intestinal crypts secretes antimicrobial substances such as lysozyme and defensins?
questions.topic: Digestive System II: Small and Large Intestine

questions.q: Which epithelial type lines the lumen of the small intestine?
options: Simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells
questions.answer: Simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells
questions.topic: Digestive System II: Small and Large Intestine

questions.q: Which structural organization is characteristic of the classical hepatic lobule?
options: Portal triad at the center and central vein at the periphery
Central vein at the center and portal triads at the corners
Central vein and portal triad both at the center
Random arrangement of hepatocytes without clear axis
questions.answer: Central vein at the center and portal triads at the corners
questions.topic: Digestive System III: Accessory Organs (Liver and Gallbladder)

questions.q: Which cell type in the liver is responsible for phagocytosis of aged erythrocytes and particulate matter?
questions.topic: Digestive System III: Accessory Organs (Liver and Gallbladder)

questions.q: Which statement best describes the gallbladder mucosa?
options: Contains villi and crypts similar to small intestine
Lined by simple columnar epithelium with apical microvilli
Contains Brunner glands in the submucosa
questions.answer: Lined by simple columnar epithelium with apical microvilli
questions.topic: Digestive System III: Accessory Organs (Liver and Gallbladder)

questions.q: Which component of the portal triad carries blood rich in nutrients from the intestine to the liver?
questions.topic: Digestive System III: Accessory Organs (Liver and Gallbladder)

questions.q: The space of Disse is located between which two structures in the liver?
questions.topic: Digestive System III: Accessory Organs (Liver and Gallbladder)

questions.q: Which feature best distinguishes the exocrine pancreas from the parotid salivary gland?
options: Presence of intercalated and striated ducts
Presence of islets of Langerhans scattered among acini
Presence of mucous acini with serous demilunes
questions.answer: Presence of islets of Langerhans scattered among acini
questions.topic: Digestive System IV: Accessory Organs (Pancreas and Salivary Glands)

questions.q: Which salivary gland is almost entirely serous in its secretory units?
questions.topic: Digestive System IV: Accessory Organs (Pancreas and Salivary Glands)

questions.q: What is the main function of centroacinar cells in the pancreas?
questions.topic: Digestive System IV: Accessory Organs (Pancreas and Salivary Glands)

questions.q: Which pancreatic endocrine cell type secretes glucagon?
questions.topic: Digestive System IV: Accessory Organs (Pancreas and Salivary Glands)

questions.q: Which of the following correctly describes striated ducts in salivary glands?
options: They are lined by stratified squamous epithelium
They actively modify saliva by reabsorbing sodium and secreting potassium and bicarbonate
They are found only in minor salivary glands
They are absent in the parotid gland
questions.answer: They actively modify saliva by reabsorbing sodium and secreting potassium and bicarbonate
questions.topic: Digestive System IV: Accessory Organs (Pancreas and Salivary Glands)

questions.q: Which epithelial type lines the trachea?
options: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells
questions.answer: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells

questions.topic: Respiratory System I: Conduction and Defense

options: Produce surfactant and detoxify inhaled substances

questions.q: Which components form the blood–air barrier in the lung?
options: Type II cell cytoplasm, surfactant, and basement membrane
Alveolar epithelium, fused basal laminae, and capillary endothelium
questions.answer: Alveolar epithelium, fused basal laminae, and capillary endothelium

questions.q: Alveolar macrophages in the lung are mainly located:

On the luminal surface and in the septa of alveoli
questions.answer: On the luminal surface and in the septa of alveoli
